awd_titl_txt: Phase mixing in the fluid mechanics and kinetic theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Nonlinear mixing is a ubiquitous behavior observed in fluids and plasmas which plays an important role in understanding certain aspects of atmosphere and ocean sciences, turbulence, astrophysics and controlled fusion. For example, it is thought to be an important organizing mechanism in atmospheric dynamics that helps to explain why hurricanes retain their characteristic vortex shape for extended periods of time. Despite being a fundamental physical mechanism, the theoretical and mathematical analysis of nonlinear phase mixing has remained elusive. Moreover, many of these effects are difficult to isolate in computational or physical experiments and here mathematical analysis can provide important insights. This project specifically aims to expand our mathematical understanding by studying the effect in a variety of fundamental 'case studies' found in fluid mechanics and plasma physics.

The purpose of this program is to further the mathematical analysis of nonlinear phase mixing, generally regarded as difficult due to the appearance of highly non-normal linear evolutions and unusual regularity issues intertwined with subtle nonlinear resonances. The PI will work to develop new tools necessary to approach these problems with a focus on working towards four specific settings: the vanishing viscosity limit of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations (NSE) near the 2D Couette flow, the nonlinear instability of 3D shear flows, inviscid 'vortex axisymmetrization' in 2D Euler and Landau damping in Vlasov-Poisson (or Vlasov-Maxwell) in presence of external magnetic fields. Many related physically relevant problems exist, and may serve as intermediate steps or additional lines of research. The work in fluid mechanics will expand further on ideas employed by the PI and collaborator Nader Masmoudi in the recent work on the stability of 2D Couette flow [arXiv:1306.5028], especially the use of adaptive coordinate systems and the construction of norms which account for weakly nonlinear resonances and the non-normal transient linear behavior. The work in kinetic theory will further develop techniques used in the work of the PI and collaborators Nader Masmoudi and Clement Mouhot on Landau damping [arXiv:1311.2870], especially the efficient treatment of the plasma echoes. Most likely, in order to expand the range of kinetic theory applications, some ideas from the work in fluid mechanics may need to be adapted to the kinetic setting.

por.por_cntn:
The project was largely a success in terms of progress towards the proposed problems and those closely related to them. The goal of the project was to advance mathematical understanding of the physical mechanism often referred to as "phase mixing". This effect is thought to play a role in understanding the motion of coherent structures in fluid mechanics, such as the dynamics of hurricanes and other large vortex structures in the atmosphere and shear layers, such as found in the air flow along the hood of a car. The effect is also crucial to understanding many phenomena in plasma physics, particularly those which arise in magnetically-confined fusion devices such as Tokamaks. Very little mathematical work on this effect existed before this project started, and the PI and his collaborators have produced 10 publications and preprints, including publications appearing in top quality journals such as the Annals of Mathematics, Communications in Pure and Applied Mathematics, Memoirs of the AMS, and the Archive of Rational Mechanics and Analysis. Of particular note is the sequence of works of the PI with Pierre Germain and Nader Masmoudi which provide the first detailed mathematical study of the stability of a shear flow in the full nonlinear 3D Navier-Stokes equations of fluid mechanics and the work of the PI proving that nonlinear effects cannot be neglected when studying such questions in general. Not all of the proposed problems were solved, however, progress is currently being made, building off of the work in the Project, towards some of these problems. Moreover, the Project has opened up several new avenues of research as well, that the PI and his collaborators are now pursuing. 

Intellectual Merit: The work supported by the grant has solidly moved this field forward, taking the field from a few specific results, to providing a wider range of mathematical tools and a much clearer view of what kinds of questions are relevant, interesting, and approachable. There is still much work to be done, but this grant has laid the foundation for major future progress.

Broader impact: The work has had potential broader impact on several levels. First, between the introduction of a variety of mathematical ideas from the PI and his collaborators as well as the interest in the results themselves, a number of other mathematicians around the world have begun to focus more intently on such questions. Secondly, many of the works that the PI and his collaborators have solved were directly posed by physicists, and some had been studied in the physics literature for decades. The PI and his collaborators have hence provided progress which is of interest to physicists. The PI has spent time networking and discussing with physicists by attending physics conferences and arranging meetings with them on campus visits, especially plasma physicists, in order to broaden his perspective and focus on work of relevance to physics. The PI believes that the work will eventually make a long-term impact in both physics and mathematics.  In addition to such direct scientific impacts, over the course of the award the PI has organized an REU at U of Maryland in 2016 and taught a summer school (with Vlad Vicol) at MSRI in 2015, and given many seminars directed at graduate students and post-docs on topics related to the Project. Hence, the Project has provided an opportunity to introduce some of the recent progress to students and help to expose them to interesting new aspects of fluid mechanics and plasma physics.
